Mark Levison wrote:
> In Junit 3.8 I use a style like (BTW Not everyone on this list will agree
> its worth testing this particular case - but its a simple example of the
> style):
> 
> public void testConstructionExceptions() {
>         try {
>             new RemoveElementOperation(null);
>             fail("new RemoveElementOperation - should've thrown an
> IllegalArgumentException");
>         } catch (IllegalArgumentException iae) {// NOPMD
>         }
>     }

I like to take the catch block one step further and call 
assertTrue(true) (as has been discussed on this list), or, better yet, 
call something like pass(), which I've defined in a base TestCase to do 
just that. It makes a nice juxtaposition with the fail(), and it keeps 
style checkers from bitching about empty catch clauses.

> BTW Googling "junit test for exceptions" found both of these answers. Please
> google before asking a question.

Indeed.
